posts.cooked: Hello. I am a coder for team 1350, and we wish to iterate on our code from the 2025 season to use our limelight’s during autonomous mode. Currently we have code for using our 2 cameras (Limelight 4’s) to align to either side of the coral station to score during tele-op. However when we use it in autonomous mode, since we use pathplanner, it messes with where the robot thinks it is related to pathplanner, so the auto doesnt go where we desire it to. does anyone have any tips?
Would we not be able to do any other stuff in auto though? our placement of the cameras only lets them lineup to the coral station.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
We use both calculated trajectories and drive to pose utilizing limelight information. It gave us a highly robust auto move set this year.

Check our 2025 code repo: first95 repositories · GitHub

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked:
We are seeing this issue too. We use PathPlanner. Is it better for us to leave “reset odometry” on the path off?

Because I’m assuming what happens is we reset the odometry incorrectly, the pose estimator doesn’t update fast enough, and we miss our first piece

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
The use of PathPlanner and Limelights are both rather complicated and as you see can work together or not. If you are more specific about your autonomous system and the algorithms you are using and exactly what you mean by “messes with”, then you can get better advice.

Interpreting AprilTag positions should add to or replace your wheel and gyro odometry but you have to be selective about when and how much to believe or trust the AprilTag since they aren’t always or continuously accurate.

I’ve seen some complaints on CD about the LL4, I think, regarding its internal gyro so consider that might be hurting you and your robot gyro could be more accurate.

My team uses one LL3G upgraded and it works well in autonomous with PP auto builder and our struggles are with pushing the limits of 4 or 4+ CORAL in autonomous as sometimes it doesn’t place a CORAL correctly. We use LL and PP on the fly for auto alignment in teleop for all CORAL placements with high rate of success.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
My team never resets odometry to the AprilTag determined pose although I personally think we should have when the tag was clearly in sight. We do addVisionMeasurement with the std dev of the tag about twice the odometry value.

Getting accurate results takes a lot of work - hundreds of runs to tune all the parameters and tweak paths as other teams have pointed out. While I think we could have done better with a good resetOdometry on occasion that means more hours of tuning that we don’t have.
I think they’re talking about the “reset odometry” checkbox within the PathPlanner GUI as opposed to what is presumably the pose estimator that you’re referring to.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Thank you for that clarification. The robot has to be setup on the field accurately and then you can make that promise to PP that the robot is exactly where you told PP it is. I can’t think of a case where it isn’t perfectly clear when to promise PP the robot is in the correct position and when it isn’t. PP isn’t particularly good about drastic changes in position (but it will try).

The other idiosyncrasy about the PP and PathWeaver is they stop following the path when they think it should be over and not when the robot is in the correct pose. Teams that haven’t been highly rigorous with their path/robot constraints find they need a little bit extra driving with some variation of the 3 PID command described at From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef to finish off the final inches.

link_counts.title: From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef

posts.cooked: In our experience in having that checkbox on we did not need that much precision at all. It worked when our robot was at least 4 inches from where it should’ve been.
